Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: The Biogeography of Biotransformations for Halogenated Organic Compounds, a Comparison of the Tropics, Temperate and Sub-Arctic Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this three year summer REU program is to engage students in an international research effort to compare the ability of aquatic and sediment microbial communities in geographically distinct regions to mediate the biotransformation of historic chlorinated compounds , e.g. PCBs and a important class of emerging global contaminants, brominated flame retardants (BFRs), e.g.PBDE. All students will meet for a one week "scientific boot camp" to prepare to carry out experiments that compare the geographical differences in microbial communities and their metabolism of BFRs. Several students will then travel to China, to examine tropical microbial communities and carry out their experiments at the South China University of Technology (SCUT) and the Chinese National Academy Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry (GIG). Several students will do the same with sub-Arctic microbial communities and work at the University of Helsinki (UH). The other students will be doing parallel experiments at Rutgers with temperate climate microbial communities. All students will reconvene for one week to compare their results, share their findings and develop a set of conclusions regarding the role of biogeography on the fate of BFRs in aquatic and sediment environments. The overall impact is to have students recognize the universality of scientific inquiry regardless of international borders and the global distribution of contaminants, as well as to determine the diversity of microorganisms and their biochemical mechanisms for metabolizing new anthropogenically created organic pollutants in the environment.

The project aims to promote international exchange of students to foster science across global and cultural boundaries. The educational component will be coordinated with the research component as follows: 1) all students will meet for a week at Rutgers University at the start of the program to plan, prepare and learn about the project objectives and the coordination of efforts; 2) weekly videoconferences will take place with all participants; 3) all students and their international student partners and mentors will meet for a Student Symposium at Rutgers University at the end of the program to follow-up on their results and conclusions. The partner institutions will co-support the activities, including support of students from their own institution (SCUT and UH) to travel and participate in the Student Symposium at Rutgers. Rutgers University is one of the most diverse AAU institutions and a broad range of applicants will be sought from all over the US with special outreach to underrepresented groups through the RISE program at Rutgers and with personal contacts and recruitment visits to undergraduate institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report:

          The objective of this REU was to engage students in an international research effort to compare aquatic and sediment microbial communities in geographically distinct regions to mediate the biotransformation of widely distributed contaminants, including chlorinated and brominated organic chemicals used in industrial processes.  Students met for a 1 week "scientific boot camp" at Rutgers at the beginning of the summer to prepare and understand the geographical differences in microbial communities and their metabolism. Three students then travel to China, to examine tropical microbial communities at the South China University of Technology and were accompanied by Prof. W. Huang.  Three students studied sub-Arctic microbial communities at the University of Helsinki, Finland, accompanied by Prof. M. Haggblom.  Two to three stayed at Rutgers and work with temperate climate microbial communities supervised by Prof. L. Young.  Weekly Skype meetings of all groups were held once a week for review and summary of activities.  All students reconvene for 1 week at the end of the summer to compare results, share findings and develop a set of conclusions on role of biogeography on the fate of the contaminants in aquatic and sediment environs. The aim is to have students recognize the universality of scientific inquiry regardless of international borders, the global distribution of contaminants as well as to determine the diversity of microbes and their biochemical mechanisms for metabolizing widely distributed halogenated organic pollutants.

            Over the 3 years of the grant, a total of 25 students (9, 8, 8) participate in the REU and we received a total of 110 applicants.  The demographics include, 16 female, 9 male, 4 Hispanic, 1 African-American, 3 Asian-American students. Ten students were from colleges with limited research opportunities, 5 from Rutgers with the overall distribution of students from 12 different states and territories.  Their average GPA = 3.55.  In addition to their academic record, reference letters and a personal statement, we looked for an expression of interest in a challenging international science experience and selected students mostly with a preference to those who had limited personal international travel experience in order to provide the opportunity to broaden their experience and outlook.  Critical to understanding and solving environmental issues, the student groups were purposefully arranged to form 3 person teams (except in NJ for the last 2 yrs, where there were 2 students each yr) with different backgrounds in environmental engineering, environmental sciences, chemistry, biology, biochemistry or molecular biology, so that each student can contribute their expertise to the project and to underscore that environmental problems require a multi-disciplinary approach.

          In terms of student outcome and follow-up, at least 16 have applied to graduate schools (of those whom we have information).  I have written recommendation letters for at least 12 students.  Clearly, the students who seek out and apply to REU programs, including ours, are among the most highly motivated, have strong academic records, and are likely to seek post-graduate studies.
